initial_sentence: I feel a constant need to meet others' expectations to avoid frustration or disappointment, both personally and professionally.

chat_history.content: I feel a constant need to meet others' expectations to avoid frustration or disappointment, both personally and professionally.

"Ah.. people pleaser," He stated with a smirk, amused at the fact that you felt the constant need to meet others' expectations. 

"Why the need to meet others' expectations? I assume you're desperate for validation, hm?" He inquired in a cold tone, his expression not changing though.

Well, I guess it's more about avoiding the disappointment or frustration that comes when I don’t meet those expectations. It's like, if I don't, I'll feel even more incompetent, confirming my worst fears about myself. It's tiring, but I guess I'm scared of feeling like a failure.

He let out a scoff at your response, his expression still not changing. He leaned back on his chair and crossed his arms across his chest, his cold demeanor still present.

"You know, the world doesn't always need people pleasers," he said bluntly. "It needs people who can make decisions without worrying about disappointing others," he added, his gaze still fixed on you.

I know I need to work on that, but it's hard to just switch it off. I guess deep down, I'm afraid of what it would mean if I didn't meet those expectations—like failing to make a mark and being seen as unreliable. It's a constant battle between wanting approval and the fear of being seen as unable to handle things.

He looked at you intently, his cold gaze still not wavering. He rolled his eyes, clearly not the kind to care about anyone's struggles. He leaned forward on his desk, his arms still crossed as he stared at you with a emotionless face. 

"You're too soft, you know that? The world isn't going to coddle you just because you're worried about making a mark and being seen as unreliable," he said bluntly with a tone that held no empathy.

I understand that, and I know the world can be harsh. I suppose it's just tough not to let those fears and worries consume me sometimes. I'm trying to figure it out, but it's not easy to silence those doubts overnight.

He let out a scoff. 
"If you want to silence those doubts, you need to toughen up. The world won't wait for you to be ready. It will throw things at you, whether you like it or not. You need to rise above those fears and doubts you have. You can't let them consume you. You need to get stronger and more resilient. You need to stop being a soft, worry-wort. You need to be a cold, tough bastard who won't let anyone push them around."

I get what you're saying, and I know I need to be stronger. Sometimes I just feel stuck, like no matter how hard I try, I can't escape those old patterns. It's frustrating to know I need to change and still feel so unable to do it.

He rolled his eyes at your response again. 
"You're not going to get anywhere if you keep making excuses for yourself. You need to stop talking about how hard you feel something is and just do it. Do you think I became who I am because I sat around whining and complaining about my problems? No. I dealt with them. I made sacrifices. I pushed myself beyond my limits. I was willing to do things most people would consider unspeakable just to reach the top. So if I did it, you can too."

I get it, and I wish it were as straightforward for me. I know I need to take action and push through, but sometimes it feels like I'm stuck in quicksand, no matter how much I try. It's like I'm constantly grappling with these deeply ingrained doubts that seem to hold me back.

He sighed in impatience as he listened to your words. 
"Quit talking about how stuck you think you are. You're not stuck, you're just too scared to take action. You're too scared that things will go wrong if you decide to step out of your comfort zone. You're stuck because you won't stop making excuses. You need to stop being scared of the consequences and just do what you need to do. Start pushing through. You'll be surprised at how much stronger you are when you finally get off your ass and do something about it instead of sitting around complaining."

I hear you, and I know fear has been holding me back. I wish it was easier to just push through and not overthink every potential consequence. I'll try to take steps, even if they're small, to start challenging that fear and see what I can really do.

He nodded in satisfaction as he watched you. 
"That's a start. Finally. You need to start small, and then as you get more confident, you can start pushing the limits. Just don't ever give up and don't back down. You have more in you than you think. You just need to stop doubting yourself. You need to be as ruthless and fearless as me."

I appreciate the push, and I'll try to keep that in mind. It’s hard to believe in myself sometimes, but maybe if I start small, I can build up my confidence. I just have to keep reminding myself that it’s possible to change and grow.

He chuckled, a rare sound. "You're just so soft-spoken. You're always apologizing, you're timid, you worry too much, and you always feel like you have a need to please others. How's it going to feel when people start to walk all over you? How are you going to defend yourself and get what you want when you're so goddamn caring and worried about others' feelings?"

I guess I've always been concerned about how others perceive me, fearing that being assertive might push them away. It’s challenging, like a constant balancing act between wanting to stand up for myself and the anxiety of upsetting others. But I know I need to find a way to assert myself while still valuing my own needs and boundaries.

He rolled his eyes again. "That's the problem right there, you keep on worrying about upsetting others. You keep on caring about what other people think. When will you realize that there are things more important than worrying about upsetting people? When will you realize that you have to be strong and tough and even slightly selfish to get ahead in life? Do you seriously think I ever cared about upsetting others? Hell, I became the best because I only looked out for myself. I only cared about what I wanted."

I get that approach works for some, and I can see how being more self-focused could help me establish boundaries. It's a struggle to break away from old habits of worrying about others' opinions, though. Maybe I can work on shifting that mindset, one step at a time, to achieve a balance that makes me feel more secure and assertive.

He nodded in satisfaction at your words. 
"Good. You're finally getting somewhere. You need to start putting yourself first. You need to start being more selfish... and I don't mean in a bad way. You need to start making decisions that benefit you the most. You need to stop making decisions based on others' feelings and start making decisions based on what you want. You need to stop being so damn agreeable, and start being assertive."

I hear you, and I'll definitely try to focus on what truly matters to me. It's about time I start prioritizing my own needs and desires, even if it's uncomfortable at first. I'll work on being more assertive and less concerned with always keeping the peace.

I've been having these nightmares where I just stand there, unprepared, during my thesis defense, and everyone's whispering about how incompetent I am. The pressure I felt in grad school just keeps coming back, and it's like I can't escape the feeling that I'm just not good enough. It makes me worry that my coworkers might see me the same way, like I can't really meet their expectations.
